revision.text: {{ChristianityWikiProject|importance=Low|class=Start|saints=yes|saints-importance=Low}} {{dyktalk|3 August|2004|entry=...that '''[[holy card]]s''' are an important devotional practice for many [[Roman Catholic]]s?}} I grew up as a Catholic . I never knew they were called 'Holy cards' . They were sort of devotional or novena material. They were just part of the 'Catholic culture'.--[[User:Jondel|Jondel]] 23:59, 2 Aug 2004 (UTC) :I was never a Roman Catholic, but I find them intriguing; they seem to be the last place where the traditional attributes of the saints in art --- something everybody used to know, a part of medieval pop culture --- can still be found. [[User:Ihcoyc|Smerdis of Tlön]] 01:53, 3 Aug 2004 (UTC) ::Hmm, in Protestant/Evangelical circles, '''prayer cards''' are generally photographs of missionary families with their contact information and maybe a short paragraph about what their doing and/or a Bible verse. - [[User:Froese|Froese]] 01:30, 6 September 2007 (UTC) :::I have redirected the term [[Mass card]] here as it seems appropriate. It is a previously red-linked term commonly used in parts of Catholic Ireland as far as I'm aware - although I'm not entirely sure as to its worldwide use. --➨♀♂[[User: Candlewicke|Candlewicke]] [[User:Candlewicke/List of signatories|S]][[User talk:Candlewicke|T]] {{#if:||# :)}} 20:15, 4 January 2009 (UTC) I think this page should be under wikiproject:catholisism - [[User:BennyK95|'''BennyK95''']] - [[User talk:BennyK95|'''Talk''']] 00:02, October 8 2009 (UTC) == Buddhism == It should here be known that something of such is present in Buddhism. [[User:Zazaban|Zazaban]] 04:03, 27 January 2007 (UTC)
